greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the smallest k > 0 such that there are exactly n numbers whose sum of proper divisors is k.
comment: Minimal values for nodes of exact degree in aliquot sequences. Find each node's degree (number of predecessors) in aliquot sequences and choose the smallest value as the sequence member. - Ophir Spector, ospectoro (AT) yahoo.com Nov 25 2007
link: Daniel Mondot, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..5646 (First 157 terms from Ophir Spector. First 1000 terms from Ophir Spector and Donovan Johnson.)
Daniel Mondot, A-file, extended version of b-file but with some gaps towards the end.
J. O. M. Pedersen, Tables of Aliquot Cycles [Broken link]
J. O. M. Pedersen, Tables of Aliquot Cycles [Via Internet Archive Wayback-Machine]
J. O. M. Pedersen, Tables of Aliquot Cycles [Cached copy, pdf file only]
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Aliquot sequence
example: a(4) = 37 since there are exactly four numbers (155, 203, 299, 323) whose sum of proper divisors is 37. For k < 37 there are either fewer or more numbers (32, 125, 161, 209, 221 for k = 31) whose sum of proper divisors is k.
results.author: _Klaus Brockhaus_, Nov 27 2006
